div.head:
Embleme 33. of the Secrets of Nature.
The Hermaphrodite lying like a dead man in darknesse, wants fire.

lg.l: See here the cold and dry Hermaphrodite,
Appears as dismalldismal as a ghost by night:
Fire is the thing hee wants, if that you give,
His Spirits feeling warmth will soone revive.
The Stone's whole virtue in God Vulcan lyes,
Sulphurs in Sol, in Luna Mercurye'sMercury's.

div.head: Discourse 33.
div.ab:
It is one of the secrets of Nature, that in the cold winter FroggsFrogs and-
Horse-leeches lye as it were dead under water, and in the Spring new-
heat of the Sunne operating recover sense and motion, or performe-
the actions of a sensitive life: But if they be found in the waters-
in the winter time, and brought into the aire or a warme house, they
presently begin to move themselves, as in the Summer: From whence
it appears, that they want nothing but externall heat, to excite the
naturall internall heat, and bring it to action: After the same man
ner doe the Philosophers speake of their Hermaphrodite, who, if hee
appears dead lying in darkenesse, requires the heat of fire: Now hee-
is sayd to lye in darkenesse, being left in a darke and most cold win
ters night, that is, remaining in blacknesse, which is a signe of coldnesse,
from which hee ought to be brought to whitenesse by a greater intension
of fire, and by yet a greater, to rednesse: For, as Bodillus in Turba sayth,
nothing is generated without heat, and a bath of vehement heat causethcauses-
a body to perish, if it be cold it drives it away, but if it be temperate, it
becomes agreable and pleasant to the body. Bonellus in the same sayth,
All things that live doe allso (God soe pleasing) dye: that nature there
fore, which is depriv'ddeprived of moisture, being exposdexposed by night, seems like
a dead man, and then that nature requires fire, till the body and Spi
rit of it be turned into earth, and then it becomes dust like to a dead
man in his tombetomb: these things being accomplished God restores a Spirit
and Soule to it, and all infirmity being taken away our nature is com
forted and amended: It is therefore requisite to burne that matter without
fear Ct: Fire therefore, which destroyes all other things, repairesrepairs this, that
which yeilds death to others gives life to this. One onely PhænixPhoenix there is,
which is restored by fire, which is renewed by flames, and revives out of
ashes, and this being knowne to the Philosophers onely is burnt and
restored to life, whatsoever other men dreamedream of a bird, I know not-
what, that flyethflies, residing noe where, nor seen, but as a fable. The
Hermaphrodite, of which the Philosophers speake, is of a mixd na
ture, male and female, whereof one passethpasses into another by the-
operation of heat, for the female is converted into a male, which-
ought not to seem soe strange in the Philosophers worke, it being-
found, if wee may beleive historyeshistories, that many men have allso-
changdchanged their sex: The Poetts make mention of Ceneus, Iphis, and
Tiresias, as Pontanus in the Starrs.
Pæniteat generis tamen et se Cenea malint,
Aut in fæmineam penitus transire figuram: And Ausonius:
Mæret in antiquam Ceneus revocata figuram.
Soe in the Consulship of Licinius Crassus, and Caius Cassius Longinus

at Cassinum a boy was made of a Virgin: And Licinius Mutianus in Pli
ny relates, that hee had seen one Aristotles at Argos, called allso by the-
name of Aristotle, who was marrydmarried, and soone after discovered a beard-
and virility, and marrydmarried a wife: Pliny himselfe sayth that in Africa
hee saw Lucius Cossicius a Citizen of Tisdritane chang'dchanged into a woman
on the day of mariagemarriage: certaine it is that these things are true, and-
might be proved by many other examples, if need were: but the geni
tallgenital or virile parts are thrust out of the body by the encreaseincrease of heat:
For a woman being much colder than a man, and having inwardly-
those things absconded, which a man hath outwardly, as Physicians-
say, hereupon Nature being dubious, whether Shee Should generate a-
man or a woman, hath expressdexpressed a woman outwardly, though inwardly-
shee conceivdconceived a man: for which reason heat and motion increasing-
through age the hidden parts broke forth, and shewdshowed themselves visibly
to all men: After the same manner with the Philosophers the woman is
turndturned into a man heat being increased, that is, the Hermaphrodite loo
sethlooses the female sex, and becomes a man stout and grave, having-
nothing in him of effeminacy or levity. Soe wee some time since-
saw a noble youth an Hermaphrodite changed or rather promoted (by
the industry of the ChirurgicallSurgical art performd by that most famous
Physician Caspius Tagliacolius of Bononia) into a perfect man, fit (as
was desired) for the generating of an offspring, a new hole being made
through the yard, which was wanting there, and the lower as appertai
ning to the woman being stopd up. The Philosophers are not without
all these manuall operations: for when the coldnesse and moistnessemoistness of-
Luna appears, that they call the woman, when the heat and siccity of
Sol, the man; when all those four qualityes together, being their Rebis or Her
maphrodite; And thus conversion of the woman may easily be made,
that is, the mutation of coldnesse and moistnessemoistness, into the man, which is
done by the sole heat of fire, as hath been sayd; for heat sequesters,-
and separates the superfluityes of moistures, and will establish the-
idea of itselfe in the Philosophicall subject, which is the tincture. .
